choices.text: As reverse transcriptase inhibitor
By inhibiting the HIV entry into the cell

questions.text: Efavirenz is used for treatment of HIV infections. It acts?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. As reverse transcriptase inhibitor

 

Option B:

 

Efavirenz is a non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NNRTI) used in the treatment of HIV infections. It works by binding to and inhibiting the reverse transcriptase enzyme, which is crucial for the HIV virus to replicate its RNA into DNA, a necessary step in the virus's life cycle. By inhibiting reverse transcriptase, efavirenz prevents the virus from multiplying and spreading throughout the body.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. As a protease inhibitor: Incorrect, efavirenz does not inhibit the protease enzyme.

 

Option C. As an integrase inhibitor: Incorrect, efavirenz does not affect the integrase enzyme.

 

Option D. By inhibiting the HIV entry into the cell: Incorrect, efavirenz does not block the entry of HIV into cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anti-retroviral Drugs

questions.text: Multidrug regimen shown in figure is for treatment of:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Leprosy

 

Option A:

 

Figure shows Multi drug therapy (MDT) for multibacillary and paucibacillary leprosy.

 

  • MDT treatment for leprosy is provided in blister packs, each containing four weeks (28 days) treatment.
  • The top row is breakable. It contains 2 capsules of rifampicin 300 mg each, 3 capsules of clofazimine 100 mg each and one tablet of dapsone 100 mg. All these tablets need to be taken on day 1 as supervised dose.
  • Then, there are 27 tablets each of clofazimine 50 mg and dapsone 100 mg. These two tablets must be taken once daily at home from day 2 to day 28.
  • When this pack finishes, the patient with return to hospital to get another blister pack in the same manner.
  • For MB leprosy, the treatment is for 12 months and for pauci-bacillary it is for 6 months.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. HIV: Incorrect because the drugs listed (rifampicin, clofazimine, and dapsone) are not used in the treatment of HIV. HIV treatment typically involves antiretroviral therapy (ART) which uses a different class of drugs.

 

Option C. Malaria: Incorrect as malaria treatment does not involve rifampicin, clofazimine, or dapsone. Malaria is generally treated with antimalarial medications like artemisinin-based combination therapies (ACTs).

 

Option D. Tuberculosis: Incorrect because, while rifampicin is used in the treatment of tuberculosis, the specific combination with clofazimine and dapsone, and the structured blister pack dosing, is not characteristic of tuberculosis treatment, which usually involves a combination of rifampicin with other drugs like isoniazid, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a fever, headache, and muscle aches. He reports a recent camping trip in a rural area where he was exposed to ticks. On examination, there is a characteristic eschar at the site of a tick bite, as well as regional lymphadenopathy. Laboratory tests reveal thrombocytopenia and elevated liver enzymes. Based on the clinical presentation and laboratory findings, the healthcare provider suspects scrub typhus. What is the drug of choice for scrub typhus?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Doxycycline.

 

Option D:

 

  • Scrub typhus is an acute febrile illness caused by the bacteria Orientia tsutsugamushi, which is transmitted to humans by the bite of infected chiggers. The clinical presentation of scrub typhus is characterized by fever, headache, muscle aches, and the presence of an eschar at the site of the chigger bite. Laboratory findings may include thrombocytopenia, elevated liver enzymes, and leukocytosis.
  • The drug of choice for the treatment of scrub typhus is doxycycline. Other antibiotics, such as azithromycin, chloramphenicol, and ciprofloxacin, may also be used to treat scrub typhus, but doxycycline is the preferred drug due to its effectiveness and low risk of adverse effects.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Erythromycin: While it can be used for some rickettsial diseases, it is not the first-line treatment for scrub typhus.

 

Option B. Metronidazole: This is primarily used for anaerobic bacterial infections and certain protozoal infections, not for scrub typhus.

 

Option C. Sulfonamides: These are not effective against the organism that causes scrub typhus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Doxycycline is the drug of choice for scrub typhus due to its effectiveness in treating infections caused by Orientia tsutsugamushi. Early treatment is crucial to prevent complications and improve outcomes in patients with this condition.

questions.text: A middle-aged man with chronic renal failure is diagnosed to have sputum positive pulmonary tuberculosis. His creatinine clearance is 25 ml/min. All of the following drugs need modification in doses except.
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Rifampicin

 

Option C:

 

Rifampicin is primarily metabolized by the liver and secreted into the bile, which means its pharmacokinetics are not significantly affected by renal function. Therefore, in patients with renal failure, Rifampicin does not typically require a dose adjustment.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Isoniazid: It is partially eliminated by the kidneys, so dose adjustment may be necessary in patients with renal failure to prevent toxicity.

 

Option B. Streptomycin: It is eliminated by the kidneys, and its dose needs to be adjusted in patients with renal failure to avoid toxic accumulation.

 

Option D. Ethambutol: This drug is also eliminated through the kidneys, and dosing must be modified in patients with reduced renal function to prevent toxicity, particularly optic neuritis.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Fluoroquinolone contraindicated in liver disease is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Pefloxacin

 

Pefloxacin is metabolized significantly by the liver and is known for potential hepatotoxic effects, making it relatively contraindicated in patients with liver disease. Its use can lead to elevated liver enzymes and hepatotoxicity, especially in those with existing liver impairment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Levofloxacin - This antibiotic is partially metabolized by the liver but primarily excreted by the kidneys. It is generally considered safe for use in patients with liver disease, although renal function must be monitored for appropriate dosing adjustments.

 

Option C. Ciprofloxacin - Ciprofloxacin is mainly excreted unchanged in the urine, with minimal liver metabolism. It is considered safe for use in patients with liver disease, though dosing adjustments based on renal function are necessary.

 

Option D. Lomefloxacin - Similar to ciprofloxacin, lomefloxacin is mostly eliminated through the kidneys, with little involvement of the liver. It is generally safe for patients with liver disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The objective here is to understand the pharmacokinetics of different fluoroquinolones, particularly their metabolism and excretion pathways, to make informed decisions about their use in patients with liver disease. Recognizing that pefloxacin has a significant hepatic metabolism and is associated with hepatotoxicity can guide safer antibiotic choices in clinical settings involving compromised liver function.

choices.text: Caspofungin has been approved for invasive aspergillosis.
Voriconazole has good activity against aspergillosis.
Itraconazole is the drug of choice for life-threatening histoplasmosis.
Systemic fluconazole is the drug of choice in mucocutaneous and oral candidiasis.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about antifungals?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Itraconazole is the drug of choice for life-threatening histoplasmosis.

 

Option C:

 

The statement about Itraconazole being the drug of choice for life-threatening histoplasmosis is false. For severe histoplasmosis infections, particularly those that are life-threatening, the recommended first-line treatment is Liposomal Amphotericin B, which is more potent and has better efficacy for systemic infections. Itraconazole is used for milder, non-life-threatening cases or as a follow-up treatment after initial stabilization with Amphotericin B.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Caspofungin: This statement is true as Caspofungin, an echinocandin, is approved for treating invasive aspergillosis, especially in patients who are intolerant to or refractory to other antifungal treatments.

 

Option B. Voriconazole: Also true, Voriconazole is well-recognized for its efficacy against Aspergillosis and is a preferred treatment for invasive forms of this fungal infection.

 

Option D. Systemic fluconazole: This statement is accurate as fluconazole is commonly used and is the drug of choice for treating mucocutaneous and oral candidiasis due to its effectiveness and favorable profile for these types of Candida infections.

 

Educational objective:

 

DOC for important fungal infections

questions.text: Absorption of which of the following drugs is increased after a fatty meal?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Griseofulvin

 

Option B:

 

Griseofulvin is an antifungal medication used to treat fungal infections of the skin, hair, and nails. Its absorption from the gastrointestinal tract is increased by the presence of a fatty meal. This is because Griseofulvin is more soluble in fats, and the increased bile secretion associated with a fatty meal enhances its absorption.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Amphotericin: Incorrect. Amphotericin, another antifungal drug, is typically administered intravenously because it has poor oral bioavailability. A fatty meal would not significantly affect its absorption.

 

Option C. Ampicillin: Incorrect. Although ampicillin can be affected by food, a fatty meal does not significantly increase its absorption; in fact, food can sometimes decrease the absorption of ampicillin.

 

Option D. Aspirin: Incorrect. Aspirin's absorption is not significantly influenced by the fat content of a meal. Aspirin is an NSAID that is absorbed in the stomach and upper intestine, and its absorption can be faster on an empty stomach.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Important drugs whose absorption increase with food are:

 

  • Griseofulvin
  • Statins
  • Halofantrine
  • Protease inhibitors

choices.text: Alteration of drug binding sites
Alteration of dihydrofolate reductase
Inactivation of drug by enzymes
Efflux of drug by bacteria

questions.text: The bacterial resistance to Tigecycline is due to?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Efflux of drug by bacteria

 

Option D:

 

Tigecycline, a glycylcycline antibiotic and a derivative of tetracycline, encounters resistance predominantly through the bacterial efflux mechanism. Bacterial cells may utilize efflux pumps, which are protein transport systems embedded in their cell membranes, to actively expel the drug from the cell, thereby reducing its intracellular concentration and effectiveness. This mechanism helps the bacteria avoid the inhibitory effects of the drug on protein synthesis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Alteration of drug binding sites: While this is a common resistance mechanism for some antibiotics, it is not the primary mechanism for resistance to tigecycline.

 

Option B. Alteration of dihydrofolate reductase: This mechanism is relevant to drugs that target folate synthesis, such as sulfonamides and trimethoprim, not tigecycline.

 

Option C. Inactivation of drug by enzymes: Although some antibiotics are deactivated by bacterial enzymes, this is not a significant mode of resistance for tigecycline.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The main resistance mechanism to tigecycline is the efflux of the drug by bacterial cells, which reduces the drug’s efficacy by lowering its intracellular concentration before it can inhibit bacterial protein synthesis.

questions.text: Which antitubercular agent is associated with orange discoloration of urine?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Rifampicin

 

Option B:

 

Rifampicin is well-known for causing orange discoloration of urine and other secretions. This effect is due to the presence of its colored metabolites. Rifampicin is a potent bactericidal antibiotic that is effective against both dividing and non-dividing mycobacteria. It works by inhibiting the DNA-dependent RNA polymerase in these bacteria, crucial for their RNA synthesis and thus, their ability to reproduce.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Isoniazid: Isoniazid does not cause discoloration of urine. It's primarily associated with risk of hepatotoxicity and peripheral neuropathy.

 

Option C. Pyrazinamide: Pyrazinamide does not cause discoloration of urine. Known side effects include hepatotoxicity and hyperuricemia.

 

Option D. Ethambutol: Ethambutol does not cause discoloration of urine. The main risk with ethambutol is optic neuropathy, which can affect vision.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rifampicin (R)

 

  • It is a derivative of rifamycin (other derivatives are rifabutin and rifapentine).
  • It is bactericidal against both dividing and non-dividing mycobacterium and acts by inhibiting DNA dependent RNA polymerase.
  • Its metabolites are colored and can cause orange discoloration of the urine and secretions.
  • It can also cause orange staining of contact lens.
  • It is eliminated mainly in the feces and can be used safely in renal dysfunction.
  • Food interferes with absorption; therefore, it must be given an empty stomach.
  • It is equally effective against intra- and extra-cellular bacilli.
  • It is the most effective and fastest acting drug in leprosy.
  • It is also hepatotoxic and may cause skin rash, flu like syndrome (more prominent with intermittent regimen) and anemia.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man from a rural area presents with recurrent seizures over the past few months. He reports that he has been experiencing a persistent headache and has noticed changes in his vision. On further evaluation, he is diagnosed with neurocysticercosis caused by Taenia solium, which is a parasitic infection of the central nervous system. Which of the following drugs is the most appropriate choice for the treatment of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Albendazole.

 

Option C:

 

  • Albendazole is the most appropriate choice for treating neurocysticercosis
  • Neurocysticercosis is caused by the larval stage of Taenia solium, which is a parasitic infection of the central nervous system. Treatment of neurocysticercosis usually involves a combination of antiparasitic drugs and anti-inflammatory agents.
    • Albendazole is the drug of choice for the treatment of neurocysticercosis. It is a broad-spectrum anthelmintic agent that is effective against a variety of parasitic infections, including neurocysticercosis. It works by inhibiting the formation of microtubules in the parasite, which ultimately leads to its death.
    • Another drug that can be used for treatment of neurocysticercosis is praziquantel.
    • Both albendazole and praziquantel should be given under the cover of steroids.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Pyrantel palmoate: Incorrect because it is effective only against intestinal nematodes such as Ascaris lumbricoides and Enterobius vermicularis, not against parasites affecting the central nervous system.

 

Option B. Praziquantel: While effective against neurocysticercosis, it is generally considered secondary to albendazole due to its different mode of action and the scope of its anti-parasitic effects.

 

Option D. Ivermectin: Incorrect for this condition as it is mainly used for onchocerciasis (river blindness) and lymphatic filariasis, and not for neurocysticercosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Albendazole is the drug of choice for neurocysticercosis due to its effectiveness in inhibiting parasite growth and survival in the central nervous system, typically administered with corticosteroids to control inflammation during treatment.

questions.text: All are bactericidal drugs for Mycobacterium tuberculosis except?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Thioacetazone

 

Option A:

is a bacteriostatic drug used in the treatment of tuberculosis. It is less commonly used today due to its potential for severe side effects, including dermatological reactions and systemic toxicity. Its primary mode of action is inhibiting the synthesis of mycolic acids in the mycobacterial cell wall, but it does not kill the bacteria directly, hence it is considered bacteriostatic.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Kanamycin: A bactericidal aminoglycoside that is effective as a second-line drug against Mycobacterium tuberculosis, particularly in cases of multidrug-resistant TB (MDR-TB).

 

Option C. Rifabutin: A bactericidal drug closely related to rifampicin; it inhibits bacterial RNA synthesis by binding to the beta subunit of DNA-dependent RNA polymerase of the bacteria.

 

Option D. Isoniazid: Also bactericidal for Mycobacterium tuberculosis. It works by inhibiting the synthesis of mycolic acids, an essential component of the bacterial cell wall.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Anti-fungal drug with anti-inflammatory and antipruritic effect is?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Sertaconazole

 

Option B:

 

Sertaconazole is a topical antifungal agent that not only treats fungal infections but also provides additional anti-inflammatory and antipruritic (anti-itching) effects. This makes it particularly useful in the treatment of fungal infections like tinea pedis (athlete's foot), tinea cruris (jock itch), and tinea corporis (ringworm), where inflammation and itching can be significant symptoms.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Ketoconazole: While ketoconazole is a broad-spectrum antifungal that can reduce inflammation due to its anti-androgenic effects, it is primarily known for its use in antifungal treatments rather than for anti-inflammatory properties.

 

Option C. Luliconazole: Another topical antifungal used to treat skin infections. It is noted for its long-acting formulation but does not specifically offer notable anti-inflammatory or antipruritic properties.

 

Option D. Terbinafine: Mainly used for treating fungal infections of the skin and nails, terbinafine works by inhibiting the enzyme squalene epoxidase in the fungal cell membrane. It is not specifically recognized for anti-inflammatory or antipruritic effects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

New Topical Azoles (SLE)

questions.text: Combination antimicrobial therapy is not required in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Gonorrhea

 

Option A:

 

The treatment for uncomplicated gonorrhea typically involves a single dose of ceftriaxone, which is an effective monotherapy and does not routinely require combination therapy. While the CDC previously recommended combination therapy for gonorrhea (including the use of azithromycin or doxycycline), changes in guidelines due to emerging antibiotic resistance and the desire to prevent the overuse of antibiotics have led to the current recommendation of a single agent, unless there is a specific indication for dual therapy.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. TB: Tuberculosis treatment necessitates a combination of multiple drugs to effectively combat the disease and prevent the development of resistance. The intensive phase uses four drugs (HRZE - isoniazid, rifampicin, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol), followed by a continuation phase with three drugs (HRE - isoniazid, rifampicin, and ethambutol).

 

Option C. Malaria: The treatment of malaria often involves artemisinin-based combination therapy (ACT) to increase efficacy and combat resistance.

 

Option D. Intra-Abdominal infection: Typically treated with combination antibiotics to cover the broad spectrum of potential pathogens, including anaerobic and aerobic bacteria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Combination antibiotic therapy: Combination antimicrobial therapy is commonly used in the treatment of certain infectious diseases to increase efficacy, prevent the development of drug resistance, and reduce the risk of treatment failure. However, not all infectious diseases require combination therapy.

 

Well established indications for combination antimicrobial therapy include:

 

  • Tuberculosis
  • Malaria
  • HIV
  • pylori
  • Febrile neutropenia
  • Intraabdominal infections

choices.text: Candida glabrata- Amphotericin B

questions.text: Which of the following organisms is correctly matched with the drug against which it has natural resistance?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Candida krusei- fluconazole

 

Option D:

 

Candida krusei is intrinsically resistant to fluconazole, largely due to the overexpression of efflux pumps and alterations in the target enzyme, lanosterol 14-α-demethylase, which fluconazole targets to inhibit ergosterol synthesis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Candida glabrata- Amphotericin B: Candida glabrata can be resistant to fluconazole, but it generally remains susceptible to amphotericin B, which disrupts fungal cell membrane integrity by binding to ergosterol.

 

Option B. Aspergillus niger- Voriconazole: Aspergillus niger can be susceptible to voriconazole, which is a broad-spectrum antifungal effective against most Aspergillus species, including A. niger in many cases.

 

Option C. Aspergillus fumigatus- Micafungin: Aspergillus fumigatus is generally susceptible to micafungin, an echinocandin that inhibits the synthesis of β-1,3-glucan, an essential component of the fungal cell wall. However, echinocandins are not the first-line treatment for aspergillosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Candida krusei is known for its intrinsic resistance to fluconazole, an important consideration in the treatment of fungal infections to ensure that the chosen antifungal therapy is likely to be effective.

choices.text: Flu like syndrome is usually seen with rifampicin when taken on daily basis.
Ethambutol accumulates in renal failure.
Hyperuricemia is a recognized side effect of pyrazinamide.
Red and green color impairment is an early sign of ethambutol induced optic neuritis.

questions.text: All the following are true about the therapy of tuberculosis except?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Flu-like syndrome is usually seen with rifampicin when taken on a daily basis.

 

Option A:

 

The flu-like syndrome associated with rifampicin is more commonly seen when the drug is taken intermittently (e.g., once or twice weekly) rather than on a daily basis. The syndrome is thought to be due to an immunological reaction and can include symptoms such as fever, chills, headache, dizziness, and bone pain.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Ethambutol accumulates in renal failure: This is true. Ethambutol is excreted by the kidneys, and in the event of renal impairment, it can accumulate in the body, which requires dosage adjustments to avoid toxicity.

 

Option C. Hyperuricemia is a recognized side effect of pyrazinamide: This is also true. Pyrazinamide can cause an increase in serum uric acid levels, sometimes leading to gouty arthritis.

 

Option D. Red and green color impairment is an early sign of ethambutol-induced optic neuritis: This statement is accurate. Optic neuritis, a potential side effect of ethambutol, often presents as a difficulty in distinguishing red from green.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rifampicin's flu-like syndrome is more likely to occur with intermittent dosing than with daily dosing. It is important for clinicians to be aware of the side effects and necessary dose adjustments of antitubercular drugs, especially in the context of renal failure, to manage TB effectively while minimizing adverse effects.

choices.text: It has cross resistance with clofazimine.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with a history of extensively drug-resistant tuberculosis (XDR-TB) is prescribed bedaquiline as part of their treatment regimen. The patient asks about the medication and its potential side effects. Which of the following statements about bedaquiline is FALSE?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. It should be given alone.

 

Option C:

 

Bedaquiline is a medication used in the treatment of drug-resistant tuberculosis (TB). It is a member of a new class of anti-TB drugs called diarylquinolines and works by inhibiting the mycobacterial ATP synthase enzyme, which is essential to produce energy in the bacteria. By inhibiting this enzyme, bedaquiline disrupts the energy production process in the bacteria, leading to their death.

 

Bedaquiline is typically given in combination with other anti-TB medications to create a comprehensive treatment regimen. This combination therapy is designed to improve the effectiveness of the treatment and reduce the likelihood of the bacteria developing resistance to any one medication. Therefore, option (c) is false.

 

Other Optons:

 

Option A. Mycobacterial ATP synthase inhibitor: True; bedaquiline works by inhibiting the ATP synthase enzyme in mycobacteria.

 

Option B. Food intake increases bioavailability: True; The bioavailability of bedaquiline is enhanced by food intake, especially high-fat meals, so it is recommended that the medication be taken with meals.

 

Option D. It has cross-resistance with clofazimine: True, as both drugs can have effects on similar targets within the mycobacteria, leading to potential cross-resistance issues.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bedaquiline should always be used as part of combination therapy when treating extensively drug-resistant tuberculosis (XDR-TB) to ensure comprehensive management of the disease and to minimize the risk of developing drug resistance.

choices.text: Acts as a substrate for P-glycoprotein (P-gp)
Undergo hepatic oxidative metabolism.
Protease inhibitors interfere with metabolism of several drugs.
Saquinavir causes maximum induction of CYP3A4.

questions.text: True about protease inhibitors are all except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Saquinavir causes maximum induction of CYP3A4.

 

Option D:

 

Protease inhibitors, used in the treatment of HIV, are known for their interactions with drug-metabolizing enzymes, but the statement about Saquinavir is incorrect. Saquinavir does not induce CYP3A4; rather, it is a weak inhibitor of this enzyme. CYP3A4 is a crucial enzyme in the metabolism of many drugs, and its inhibition by protease inhibitors like Saquinavir can lead to significant drug interactions by increasing the plasma concentrations of drugs metabolized by CYP3A4.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Acts as a substrate for P-glycoprotein (P-gp): True. Protease inhibitors are recognized as substrates for P-glycoprotein, which can affect their absorption and elimination.

 

Option B. Undergo hepatic oxidative metabolism: True. Protease inhibitors generally undergo extensive metabolism in the liver, primarily via CYP3A4, which is significant for their pharmacokinetic profiles.

 

Option C. Protease inhibitors interfere with metabolism of several drugs: True. Due to their role as inhibitors of CYP3A4 and, in some cases, other cytochrome P450 enzymes, protease inhibitors can interfere with the metabolism of many other drugs, leading to increased drug levels and potential toxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While protease inhibitors are crucial in managing HIV due to their ability to inhibit the viral protease enzyme, they are also involved in multiple drug interactions due to their effects on drug-metabolizing enzymes. Saquinavir, in particular, is a weak inhibitor of CYP3A4 and does not induce it, which can influence the choice and management of concurrent medications in patients receiving this drug.

choices.text: Tenofovir- inhibits assembly of proviral components into viral proteins.
Enfuvirtide-An entry inhibitor- inhibits viral entry by binding to CCR5 receptor.
Ritonavir-A nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor.
Dolutegravir- inhibits integration of Viral DNA into host.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is correctly matched with its mechanism of action?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Dolutegravir- inhibits integration of Viral DNA into host.

 

Option D:

 

Dolutegravir is an integrase inhibitor, a class of antiretroviral drugs that prevent the integration of viral DNA into the host cell DNA by inhibiting the HIV integrase enzyme. This action effectively prevents the virus from replicating in the host cell.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Tenofovir: This is incorrectly matched. Tenofovir is a nucleotide reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NtRTI), not an inhibitor of the assembly of proviral components. It works by incorporating itself into the viral DNA being synthesized and causing termination.

 

Option B. Enfuvirtide: Incorrectly matched. Enfuvirtide is a fusion inhibitor, not a CCR5 receptor binder. It prevents HIV from entering host cells by binding to the gp41 subunit of the viral envelope, inhibiting viral fusion with the host cell membrane.

 

Option C. Ritonavir: Also incorrectly matched. Ritonavir is a protease inhibitor, not a nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor. It works by inhibiting the HIV protease enzyme, which is necessary for the proteolytic cleavage of the viral polyprotein precursors into individual functional proteins that make up new virions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Tenofovir is a nucleotide reverse transcriptase inhibitor.
  • Enfuvirtide is a fusion inhibitor.
  • Ritonavir is a protease inhibitor.
  • Dolutegravir is an integrase inhibitor.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient with human immunodeficiency virus infection is being treated with a HAART (highly active antiretroviral therapy) regimen. Four weeks after initiating therapy, he presented to the emergency department complaining of fever, rash, and gastrointestinal upset. Which one of the following drugs is most likely the cause of his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Abacavir

 

Option C:

 

  • Abacavir is a nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NRTI) used in the treatment of HIV infection.
  • It is known to cause a hypersensitivity reaction in some patients, typically within the first 6 weeks of therapy.
  • The hypersensitivity reaction is characterized by fever, rash, gastrointestinal symptoms, and respiratory symptoms.
  • If left untreated, it can progress to more severe reactions such as hypotension, respiratory failure, and death.
  • Sensitized individuals should never be rechallenged because of rapidly appearing, severe reactions that may lead to death.
  • A genetic test (HLA-B*5701) is available to screen patients for the potential of this reaction.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Zidovudine: While it can cause side effects, including anemia and myopathy, it is not commonly associated with hypersensitivity reactions.

 

Option B. Nelfinavir: A protease inhibitor that may cause gastrointestinal side effects, but it is not known for a hypersensitivity reaction like that seen with abacavir.

 

Option D. Efavirenz: Known for central nervous system side effects, such as dizziness and vivid dreams, not hypersensitivity reactions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When starting a patient on abacavir, it's crucial to be vigilant for signs of hypersensitivity reactions, particularly within the first six weeks of treatment. Testing for HLA-B*5701 should be done before initiation of therapy to reduce the risk of this serious reaction.
